funcs.name: is_bool
funcs.desc: Finds whether the given variable is a boolean.

return.desc: Returns TRUE if var is a boolean, FALSE otherwise.

args.name: var
args.desc: The variable being evaluated.

funcs.name: is_int
funcs.desc:
Finds whether the type of the given variable is integer.

To test if a variable is a number or a numeric string (such as form input, which is always a string), you must use is_numeric().

return.desc: Returns TRUE if var is an integer, FALSE otherwise.

args.name: var
args.desc: The variable being evaluated.

funcs.name: is_float
funcs.desc:
Finds whether the type of the given variable is float.

To test if a variable is a number or a numeric string (such as form input, which is always a string), you must use is_numeric().

return.desc: Returns TRUE if var is a float, FALSE otherwise.

args.name: var
args.desc: The variable being evaluated.

funcs.name: is_numeric
funcs.desc: Finds whether the given variable is numeric. Numeric strings consist of optional sign, any number of digits, optional decimal part and optional exponential part. Thus +0123.45e6 is a valid numeric value. Hexadecimal notation (0xFF) is allowed too but only without sign, decimal and exponential part.

return.desc: Returns TRUE if var is a number or a numeric string, FALSE otherwise.

args.name: var
args.desc: The variable being evaluated.

funcs.name: is_string
funcs.desc: Finds whether the type given variable is string.

return.desc: Returns TRUE if var is of type string, FALSE otherwise.

args.name: var
args.desc: The variable being evaluated.

funcs.name: is_scalar
funcs.desc:
Finds whether the given variable is a scalar.

Scalar variables are those containing an integer, float, string or boolean. Types array, object and resource are not scalar.

is_scalar() does not consider resource type values to be scalar as resources are abstract datatypes which are currently based on integers. This implementation detail should not be relied upon, as it may change.

return.desc: Returns TRUE if var is a scalar FALSE otherwise.

args.name: var
args.desc: The variable being evaluated.

funcs.name: is_array
funcs.desc: Finds whether the given variable is an array.

return.desc: Returns TRUE if var is an array, FALSE otherwise.

args.name: var
args.desc: The variable being evaluated.

funcs.name: is_object
funcs.desc: Finds whether the given variable is an object.

return.desc: Returns TRUE if var is an object, FALSE otherwise.

args.name: var
args.desc: The variable being evaluated.

funcs.name: is_resource
funcs.desc: Finds whether the given variable is a resource.

return.desc: Returns TRUE if var is a resource, FALSE otherwise.

args.name: var
args.desc: The variable being evaluated.

funcs.name: is_null
funcs.desc: Finds whether the given variable is NULL.

return.desc: Returns TRUE if var is null, FALSE otherwise.

args.name: var
args.desc: The variable being evaluated.

funcs.name: gettype
funcs.desc: Returns the type of the PHP variable var. Warning Never use gettype() to test for a certain type, since the returned string may be subject to change in a future version. In addition, it is slow too, as it involves string comparison. Instead, use the is_* functions.

return.desc: Possibles values for the returned string are: "boolean" "integer" "double" (for historical reasons "double" is returned in case of a float, and not simply "float") "string" "array" "object" "resource" "NULL" "unknown type"

args.name: v
args.desc: The variable being type checked.

funcs.name: get_resource_type
funcs.desc: This function gets the type of the given resource.

return.desc:
If the given handle is a resource, this function will return a string representing its type. If the type is not identified by this function, the return value will be the string Unknown.

This function will return FALSE and generate an error if handle is not a resource.

args.name: handle
args.desc: The evaluated resource handle.

return.desc: The boolean value of var.

funcs.name: intval
funcs.desc: Returns the integer value of var, using the specified base for the conversion (the default is base 10). intval() should not be used on objects, as doing so will emit an E_NOTICE level error and return 1.

return.desc:
The integer value of var on success, or 0 on failure. Empty arrays and objects return 0, non-empty arrays and objects return 1.

The maximum value depends on the system. 32 bit systems have a maximum signed integer range of -2147483648 to 2147483647. So for example on such a system, intval('1000000000000') will return 2147483647. The maximum signed integer value for 64 bit systems is 9223372036854775807.

Strings will most likely return 0 although this depends on the leftmost characters of the string. The common rules of integer casting apply.

args.name: var
args.desc: The scalar value being converted to an integer

args.name: base
args.desc: The base for the conversion

funcs.name: floatval
funcs.desc: Gets the float value of var.

return.desc: The float value of the given variable. Empty arrays return 0, non-empty arrays return 1.

args.name: var
args.desc: May be any scalar type. floatval() should not be used on objects, as doing so will emit an E_NOTICE level error and return 1.

return.desc: The string value of var.

args.name: var
args.desc:
The variable that is being converted to a string.

var may be any scalar type or an object that implements the __toString method. You cannot use strval() on arrays or on objects that do not implement the __toString method.

funcs.name: settype
funcs.desc: Set the type of variable var to type.

return.desc: Returns TRUE on success or FALSE on failure.

args.name: var
args.desc: The variable being converted.

args.name: type
args.desc: Possibles values of type are: "boolean" (or, since PHP 4.2.0, "bool") "integer" (or, since PHP 4.2.0, "int") "float" (only possible since PHP 4.2.0, for older versions use the deprecated variant "double") "string" "array" "object" "null" (since PHP 4.2.0)

funcs.name: print_r
funcs.desc:
print_r() displays information about a variable in a way that's readable by humans.

print_r(), var_dump() and var_export() will also show protected and private properties of objects with PHP 5. Static class members will not be shown.

Remember that print_r() will move the array pointer to the end. Use reset() to bring it back to beginning.

return.desc:
If given a string, integer or float, the value itself will be printed. If given an array, values will be presented in a format that shows keys and elements. Similar notation is used for objects.

When the return parameter is TRUE, this function will return a string. Otherwise, the return value is TRUE.

args.name: expression
args.desc: The expression to be printed.

args.name: ret
args.desc: If you would like to capture the output of print_r(), use the return parameter. When this parameter is set to TRUE, print_r() will return the information rather than print it.

return.desc: Returns the variable representation when the return parameter is used and evaluates to TRUE. Otherwise, this function will return NULL.

args.name: expression
args.desc: The variable you want to export.

args.name: ret
args.desc:
If used and set to TRUE, var_export() will return the variable representation instead of outputing it.

This function uses internal output buffering with this parameter so it can not be used inside an ob_start() callback function.

return.desc: No value is returned.

args.name: expression
args.desc: The variable you want to export.

funcs.name: debug_zval_dump
funcs.desc: Dumps a string representation of an internal zend value to output.

return.desc: No value is returned.

args.name: variable
args.desc: The variable being evaluated.

funcs.name: serialize
funcs.desc:
Generates a storable representation of a value

This is useful for storing or passing PHP values around without losing their type and structure.

To make the serialized string into a PHP value again, use unserialize().

return.desc: Returns a string containing a byte-stream representation of value that can be stored anywhere.

args.name: value
args.desc:
The value to be serialized. serialize() handles all types, except the resource-type. You can even serialize() arrays that contain references to itself. Circular references inside the array/object you are serializing will also be stored. Any other reference will be lost.

When serializing objects, PHP will attempt to call the member function __sleep prior to serialization. This is to allow the object to do any last minute clean-up, etc. prior to being serialized. Likewise, when the object is restored using unserialize() the __wakeup member function is called.

Object's private members have the class name prepended to the member name; protected members have a '*' prepended to the member name. These prepended values have null bytes on either side.

return.desc:
The converted value is returned, and can be a boolean, integer, float, string, array or object.

In case the passed string is not unserializeable, FALSE is returned and E_NOTICE is issued.

args.name: str
args.desc:
The serialized string.

If the variable being unserialized is an object, after successfully reconstructing the object PHP will automatically attempt to call the __wakeup() member function (if it exists).

unserialize_callback_func directive

It's possible to set a callback-function which will be called, if an undefined class should be instantiated during unserializing. (to prevent getting an incomplete object "__PHP_Incomplete_Class".) Use your php.ini, ini_set() or .htaccess to define 'unserialize_callback_func'. Everytime an undefined class should be instantiated, it'll be called. To disable this feature just empty this setting.

args.name: class_whitelist
args.desc: The array of the class names that are authorized to be unserialized. The array is default to be empty, which means no class is allowed. If the class name is a super class, all its subclasses are also allowed. Note that primitive types and Serializable classes are not subject to this whitelist. See http://fburl.com/SafeSerializable for the reason why we need this.

funcs.name: get_defined_vars
funcs.desc: This function returns a multidimensional array containing a list of all defined variables, be them environment, server or user-defined variables, within the scope that get_defined_vars() is called.

return.desc: A multidimensional array with all the variables.

funcs.name: import_request_variables
funcs.desc:
Imports GET/POST/Cookie variables into the global scope. It is useful if you disabled register_globals, but would like to see some variables in the global scope.

If you're interested in importing other variables into the global scope, such as $_SERVER, consider using extract().

return.desc: Returns TRUE on success or FALSE on failure.

args.name: types
args.desc:
Using the types parameter, you can specify which request variables to import. You can use 'G', 'P' and 'C' characters respectively for GET, POST and Cookie. These characters are not case sensitive, so you can also use any combination of 'g', 'p' and 'c'. POST includes the POST uploaded file information.

Note that the order of the letters matters, as when using "GP", the POST variables will overwrite GET variables with the same name. Any other letters than GPC are discarded.

args.name: prefix
args.desc:
Variable name prefix, prepended before all variable's name imported into the global scope. So if you have a GET value named "userid", and provide a prefix "pref_", then you'll get a global variable named $pref_userid.

Although the prefix parameter is optional, you will get an E_NOTICE level error if you specify no prefix, or specify an empty string as a prefix. This is a possible security hazard. Notice level errors are not displayed using the default error reporting level.

funcs.name: extract
funcs.desc:
Import variables from an array into the current symbol table.

Checks each key to see whether it has a valid variable name. It also checks for collisions with existing variables in the symbol table.

return.desc: Returns the number of variables successfully imported into the symbol table.

args.name: var_array
args.desc:
An associative array. This function treats keys as variable names and values as variable values. For each key/value pair it will create a variable in the current symbol table, subject to extract_type and prefix parameters.

You must use an associative array; a numerically indexed array will not produce results unless you use EXTR_PREFIX_ALL or EXTR_PREFIX_INVALID.

args.name: extract_type
args.desc: The way invalid/numeric keys and collisions are treated is determined by the extract_type. It can be one of the following values: EXTR_OVERWRITE If there is a collision, overwrite the existing variable.

args.name: prefix
args.desc: If there is a collision, don't overwrite the existing variable.
